item.title: Tumor Test Helps Identify Which Breast Cancers Don't Require Extra Treatment
item.description: June 29, 2017 - Researchers say the test, which measures gene activity, can help avoid "overtreating" tumors that are not life-threatening. It might allow some patients to avoid radiation and chemotherapy.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - Researchers say the test, which measures gene activity, can help avoid "overtreating" tumors that are not life-threatening. It might allow some patients to avoid radiation and chemotherapy. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/29/534882955/tumor-test-helps-identify-which-breast-cancers-dont-require-extra-treatment

item.title: Ohio Town Struggles To Afford Life-Saving Drug For Opioid Overdoses
item.description: June 29, 2017 - In Middletown, Ohio, a city official says the opiate epidemic has caused a financial crisis. To save money, he's suggested a three strikes rule: If a drug user overdoses three times, first responders will not administer a life-saving drug.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - In Middletown, Ohio, a city official says the opiate epidemic has caused a financial crisis. To save money, he's suggested a three strikes rule: If a drug user overdoses three times, first responders will not administer a life-saving drug. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/29/534916080/ohio-town-struggles-to-afford-life-saving-drug-for-opioid-overdoses

item.title: Democrats Push Back On Senate Republican Health Care Bill
item.description: June 29, 2017 - Many Democrats were encouraged that Republicans had to push off their vote on a Senate bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, in the midst of vocal opposition from the left.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - Many Democrats were encouraged that Republicans had to push off their vote on a Senate bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, in the midst of vocal opposition from the left. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/29/534916024/democrats-push-back-on-senate-republican-health-care-bill

item.title: The Bubonic Plague Is Back, This Time In New Mexico
item.description: June 29, 2017 - In medieval times, they called it "the black death." It's still around, routinely cropping up in the U.S. This time, the New Mexico Department of Health reports three cases.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - In medieval times, they called it "the black death." It's still around, routinely cropping up in the U.S. This time, the New Mexico Department of Health reports three cases. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/06/29/534863486/the-bubonic-plague-is-back-this-time-in-new-mexico

item.title: What Happens When The Heroin Epidemic Hits Small Town America?
item.description: June 29, 2017 - West Virginia has the highest drug overdose death rate in the country. New Yorker writer Margaret Talbot interviewed addicts, their families and health professionals to understand why.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - West Virginia has the highest drug overdose death rate in the country. New Yorker writer Margaret Talbot interviewed addicts, their families and health professionals to understand why. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/29/534868012/what-happens-when-the-heroin-epidemic-hits-small-town-america

item.title: C. Diff Infections Are Falling, Thanks To Better Cleaning And Fewer Antibiotics
item.description: June 29, 2017 - The bacterium C. difficile causes one of the most common infections in hospitals and nursing homes. After climbing for decades, the rate of new infections is now falling.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - The bacterium C. difficile causes one of the most common infections in hospitals and nursing homes. After climbing for decades, the rate of new infections is now falling. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/29/534870581/c-diff-infections-are-falling-thanks-to-better-cleaning-and-fewer-antibiotics

item.title: With The Senate's Health Care Vote Delayed, What's Next For Democrats?
item.description: June 29, 2017 - Do Democrats want to work with Republicans to make the health bill better? Rachel Martin talks to Tom Perez, chairman of the Democratic National Committee.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - Do Democrats want to work with Republicans to make the health bill better? Rachel Martin talks to Tom Perez, chairman of the Democratic National Committee. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/29/534848770/with-the-senates-health-care-vote-delayed-whats-next-for-democrats

item.title: GOP Health Plan Vote Delayed, But Sen. Rounds Will Vote 'Yes'
item.description: June 29, 2017 - The Senate leadership is intent on overhauling the Affordable Care Act. Steve Inskeep talks to Republican Sen. Mike Rounds of South Dakota about why he supports the health care legislation.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - The Senate leadership is intent on overhauling the Affordable Care Act. Steve Inskeep talks to Republican Sen. Mike Rounds of South Dakota about why he supports the health care legislation. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/29/534835122/vote-on-gop-health-plan-delayed-but-sen-rounds-will-vote-yes

item.title: Senate Health Bill Needs To Change Dramatically, AARP Says
item.description: June 29, 2017 - Steve Inskeep talks to David Certner, legislative policy director for government affairs at AARP, about why his organization wants the Senate to scratch the GOP health care bill and start again.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - Steve Inskeep talks to David Certner, legislative policy director for government affairs at AARP, about why his organization wants the Senate to scratch the GOP health care bill and start again. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/29/534835080/senate-health-care-bill-needs-to-change-dramatically-aarp-says

item.title: GOP Senators From Opioid-Ravaged States Uneasy About Health Care Bill
item.description: June 29, 2017 - Sen. Shelley Moore Capito, R-W.Va., has announced that she opposes the health care bill in its current form. She cited cuts to Medicaid and what the bill would mean for people with opioid addiction.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - Sen. Shelley Moore Capito, R-W.Va., has announced that she opposes the health care bill in its current form. She cited cuts to Medicaid and what the bill would mean for people with opioid addiction. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/29/534789053/gop-senators-from-opioid-ravaged-states-uneasy-about-health-care-bill

item.title: Patients With Pre-Existing Conditions Fear Bias Under GOP Health Proposals
item.description: June 29, 2017 - Encouraged by their doctors, many people in recent years have taken tests to find out if they're at risk of disease. Now they worry the Republican health bills could make them vulnerable.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - Encouraged by their doctors, many people in recent years have taken tests to find out if they're at risk of disease. Now they worry the Republican health bills could make them vulnerable. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/29/534753016/patients-with-pre-existing-conditions-fear-bias-under-gop-health-proposals

item.title: Lawmakers Warn Senate Health Care Bill Could Worsen Opioid Crisis
item.description:
June 28, 2017 - Some senators are concerned about how the Senate Republicans health care bill would affect treatment for opioid addiction.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/06/28/534765000/lawmakers-warn-senate-health-care-bill-could-worsen-opioid-crisis
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: 55 Percent Of Americans Disapprove Of Senate Health Care Bill
item.description: June 28, 2017 - A new NPR-PBS NewsHour-Marist poll shows President Trump's approval ratings below 40 percent and approval of the GOP health care proposal in the teens. This toxic environment makes it even tougher for Republicans to forge a deal to meet their twin goals of repealing the Affordable Care Act and making affordable care more accessible.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 28, 2017 - A new NPR-PBS NewsHour-Marist poll shows President Trump's approval ratings below 40 percent and approval of the GOP health care proposal in the teens. This toxic environment makes it even tougher for Republicans to forge a deal to meet their twin goals of repealing the Affordable Care Act and making affordable care more accessible. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/28/534764993/55-percent-of-americans-disapprove-of-senate-health-care-bill

item.title: Nursing Homes Worry Proposed Medicaid Cuts Will Force Cuts, Closures
item.description: June 28, 2017 - Two-thirds of nursing home residents are paid for by Medicaid. "It's gotta be [Medicaid] or [I'm] out on the street," said one resident.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 28, 2017 - Two-thirds of nursing home residents are paid for by Medicaid. "It's gotta be [Medicaid] or [I'm] out on the street," said one resident. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/28/534764940/proposed-medicaid-cuts-likely-to-put-pressure-on-nursing-homes

item.title: Boston Surgeon Argues Senate GOP Bill Threatens Nation's Health
item.description: June 28, 2017 - NPR's Robert Siegel talks with Atul Gawande, a surgeon at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston and a staff writer for The New Yorker, about what the health care industry learned from the Affordable Care Act.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 28, 2017 - NPR's Robert Siegel talks with Atul Gawande, a surgeon at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston and a staff writer for The New Yorker, about what the health care industry learned from the Affordable Care Act. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/28/534764933/boston-surgeon-argues-senate-gop-bill-threatens-nations-health
